texts.en: Victoria is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Victoria joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Saminu, Istifanus and Nehemiah.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Victoria would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest in order to cover her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Victoria can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Victoria spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, hoping to ensure that her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to cover immediate expenses like child school fees and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for new cleaning equipment.

loans.name: Nafatiama Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe NAFATIAMA est composé de femmes mariées, elles ont en moyenne 37 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles dans le village de Siemona, préfecture de Baroueli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la République du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de céréales, de chaussure, de l’encens, de l’argile et de la galette.
Les femmes du groupe NAFATIAMA sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire.
Dans le but de satisfaire la demande énorme de leurs clientèles, elles font recours à Soro Yiriwaso.
La cliente KABA, première personne de la droite vers la gauche dans le rang des assises est analphabète, elle est actuellement vendeuse de l’encens (déodorant traditionnel). Elle compte acheter des bouteilles vides et d’autres matières premières pour encens chez les grossistes à Baroueli et les transformes en encens de qualité. Après quelques jours de traitement le produit final est embouteillé.
La vente se fait en détail et en espèce chez elle et parfois ambulante à une clientèle mixte. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000Fcfa, qui sera utilisé pour la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
The NAFATIAMA group consists of married women.  On average, they are 37 years old and have three children each.  They all live in traditional families in the Siemona village, Cercle of Baroueli, Segou Region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through neighborhood, friendship and kinship ties.  They sell grains, shoes, incense, clay and "galettes" (flat cakes).

The members of the NAFATIAMA group are on their third solidarity loan.  In order to meet their customers' very high demand, they have turned to Soro Yiriwaso. 

Kaba, the featured borrower, is in the front row, first from the right in the photo.  She is illiterate and she currently sells incense (a traditional deodorant).  She is planning to buy some empty bottles and other raw materials from wholesalers on Baroueli, in order to produce high-quality incense.  The production process takes a few days, after which the incense is put into bottles.

Kaba resells her goods on a retail basis and gets paid in cash.  She sells from home and also sometimes as an itinerant seller, to both men and women.  She is expecting to make a monthly profit of 30,000 CFA francs, which will be used to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy the raw materials necessary to make incense.

loans.name: Colette

texts.en:
Colette is a 45-year-old Lebanese married woman.  She is married and has three children. Her husband owns and operates a store that sells electrical equipment. His business was good at first, then it became slower and slower. 

After a period of financial hardship, Colette in 2013 decided to venture into private tutoring in order to create another source of income for her struggling family. Through the Kiva loan in partnership with Vitas s.a.l., Colette will purchase a large set of encyclopedia volumes that will allow her to expand her knowledge and serve as a reference for her modest, yet ambitious pupils.

loans.use: to purchase a large set of encyclopedia volumes.

loans.name: Istifanus

texts.en:
Istifanus is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Istifanus joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Monday, Maitala and Kyauta.

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Istifanus would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Istifanus can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

When asked, Istifanus spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, hoping to ensure his children eventually are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to meet expenses such as food and his children's school fees, thereby eliminating pressure to sell his corn for low prices at harvest.

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Salisu Inyas would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest in order to cover his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Salisu Inyas can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Salisu Inyas, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to cover his expenses like food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: La Hermandad Group

texts.es: Hipolito es un hombre con 4 hijos mayores,pertenece al grupo" La Hermandad "es un grupo unido y comprometido con Edaprospo,Hipolito  es ayudante albañil, trabaja 10 horas diarias se dedica a este rubro hace 25 años sus principales cliente son los vecinos que ya lo conocen por su trayectoria, Hipolito utilizara el préstamo en comprarse su trompo mezcladora y demás materiales para poder seguir creciendo,ya que se le ha hecho muy difícil por que la competencia es dura, Agradece a los inversionistas Kiva por la ayuda prestada y promete sacar provecho de esta ayuda.
texts.en:
Hipolito is a man with four adult children who belongs to the group "La Hermandad" [The Brotherhood]. The group is united and committed with Edaprospo. Hipolito is a construction worker who works 10 hour days. He has made his living in this field for 25 years. His main clients are his neighbors who already know his career path. 

Hipolito will use this loan to buy a cement mixer and the rest of the materials needed to be able to keep expanding. It has been difficult for him because  competition has been harsh. 

He thanks Kiva investors for their lent help and promises to make the best of this help.

loans.use: to buy a cement mixer and wood to use in his everyday work.

loans.name: Protea Group

texts.en:
Kuruthum, who is in her early 30’s, is single and has two children who attend school. She has been running a stationary business for two and a half years now. She works from 8 AM to 8 PM daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Kuruthum’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase the stationary she stocks and has paid back her loan successfully. She used the profit to pay school fees and cover household expenses. She will use this loan to increase the stationary she stocks. She dreams of building her own house one day.

Kuruthum will share this loan with her loan group "PROTEA," which consist of two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to purchase more stationary to stock.

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
Victor es un hombre de 31 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene dos hijos de tres y seis años de edad, y su negocio es la carpintería.
Él es independiente, emprendedor, paciente, responsable y trabajador. Su trabajo lo realiza en la localidad rural ‘El Torno’, un lugar caracterizado por reunir a productores agrícolas y compradores mayoristas que se encargan de repartir vegetales, frutas y carne a los mercados de la ciudad, de clima tropical con una temperatura que rodea los 30 grados centígrados durante todo el año.
Victor es de tez morena, cabello negro corto, estatura mediana, su lengua materna es el Quechua y habla español, su vida la comparte con su pareja que se dedica a la cocina y sus niños, el mayor estudia en la escuela y el menor se encuentra al cuidado de su mamá, viven en una casa de ladrillo que tiene agua potable y electricidad. Su negocio es la carpintería, realiza todo tipo de trabajos en madera, como; puertas, ventanas, sillas, mesas, etc. Esta es la primera secuencia de préstamos con la institución en dos años que viene realizando esta actividad. Su sueño es que sus hijos sean profesionales. Él desea realizar la compra de madera para trabajar, y también otras herramientas como pegamento, clavos, etc.
Es por esos motivos que Victor solicita un préstamo para la compra de madera para trabajar y construir un cuarto para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Victor, 31, is a man who lives with his wife.  He has two children, 3 and 6, and his business is carpentry.
He is independent, enterprising, patient, responsible, and hard-working.  He does his work in the rural location "El Torno", a place known for bringing together farmers and wholesale buyers who are charged with distributing vegetables, fruits, and meat to the city markets.  The area has a tropical climate with a temperature of around 30 degrees Celsius year round.
Victor has brown complexion; short, black hair; is of medium height; and his mother tongue is Quechua and he speaks Spanish.  He shares his life with his wife who makes her living in the kitchen and with the children.  The older son studies in school and the younger son is in his mother's care.  They live in a brick house with electricity and running water.  His business is carpentry and he makes all kinds of things of wood, such as doors, windows, chairs, tables, etc.  This is the first sequence of loans with the institution in two years for this kind of activity.  His dream is that his children become professionals.  He wants to buy wood to work and also other tools like glue, nails, etc.
For these reasons, Victor is requesting the loan to buy wood to work and to construct a room for his sons.

loans.use: to buy wood to work and to construct a room for his children.

loans.name: Tubogorane Group

texts.fr:
J. Marie  fait partie du groupe Tubogorane et  habite à Bujumbura. Il  a 37 ans et est marié à Desiderate, une  commerçante. Ensemble ils ont 5 enfants âgés de  5 à 12 ans  dont 4 étudient.

Il fait le commerce de  poissons depuis 17 ans. 

Il est à son  deuxième  crédit à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il  obtient, il  va  augmenter son capital et acheter beaucoup de poissons   à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les années prochaines, il voudrait acheter une parcelle et voir ses enfants étudier.
texts.en:
J. Marie is a member of the Tubogorane group and he lives in Bujumbura.  He is 37 years old and married to a retailer named Desiderate.  They have five children together, between the ages of 5 and 12.  Four of their children are in school.

J. Marie has been selling fish for 17 years.  This is his second loan with Turame.  With this loan, financed by Kiva, he will increase his capital and buy a large quantity of fish for resale, in order to make a larger income.  In the coming years, he would like to buy a plot of land and continue to educate his children.

loans.use: to increase his capital and buy a large quantity of fish for resale.

loans.name: Alasan

texts.en: Alasan is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Alasan joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Climon, Manasa and Shaawa.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Alasan would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Alasan can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Alasan spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.name: Nzoriha Group

texts.fr:
Siméon  fait partie du groupe  Nzoriha  et  habite à Bujumbura. C’est un célibataire de 38 ans.

Il fait le commerce de manioc sec depuis  5 ans. 

Il est à son  deuxième  crédit à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il  obtient, il  va  augmenter son capital et acheter beaucoup de kilos de manioc sec à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les années prochaines, il voudrait devenir un commerçant grossiste de manioc sec.
texts.en:
Siméon is a member of the Nzoriha group and lives in Bujumbura. He is a 38 year old bachelor, and has been in the business of selling dried cassava for 5 years.

Siméon is on his second loan with Turame. With the Kiva loan he receives, he will increase his business capital and purchase many kilos of dried cassava to resell and increase his earnings. 

In the coming years, Siméon would like to become a wholesaler of dried cassava.

loans.use: to increase his capital and purchase many kilos of dried cassava to resell and increase his earnings

loans.name: Halisu

texts.en: Halisu is a maize farmer from Kankanki village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Halisu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Halisu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Halisu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI est composé de femmes mariées, elles ont en moyenne 34 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la République du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font la restauration, le commerce de condiments, de fruits et légumes et d’articles divers.
Les femmes du groupe BENKADI sont à leur premier prêt solidaire.
Dans le but de satisfaire la demande énorme de leurs clientèles, elles font recours à Soro Yiriwaso.
La cliente KARIA, première personne de la gauche vers la droite est analphabète, elle est actuellement restauratrice. Elle compte acheter du riz, de macaroni, de l’huile et des condiments sur place chez les grossistes.
La vente des plats se fait en espèce au marché à une clientèle mixte. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 12 000Fcfa, qui sera réinvesti dans son activité.
texts.en:
The BENKADI group is made up of married women who are, on average, 34 years old with five children each.  They all live in traditional families in the town of Dioïla, Cercle of Dioïla, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through family, neighborhood and friendship ties.  They are involved in the preparation of meals, and they also sell condiments, fruits, vegetables, and various other items.

The members of the Benkadi group are taking their first solidarity loan.  They have turned to Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the very high demand from their customers.

The group's featured borrower, Karia, standing first from the left in the photo, is illiterate and involved in the preparation of dishes.  She is planning to buy rice, macaroni pasta, oil and condiments from local wholesalers.  She sells her dishes at the market to both men and women, and she gets paid in cash.  She is expecting to make a monthly profit of 12,000 CFA francs, which will be reinvested in her activity.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to prepare and sell dishes.
